risinfo.chaptertitle: 3. Presenting Problem, History of Presenting Problem, and Social History

sect1.title: Other Psychological History
sect1.para: Regardless of a client’s presenting problem, clinicians should inquire about past and current psychological diagnoses, undiagnosed symptoms, and behavioral patterns for differential diagnosis purposes. Screening measures can be used to quickly assess a broad scope of current symptoms, with follow-up inquiry during the interview as needed. At a minimum, clinicians should ask about substance use history, trauma history, psychosis, and safety (i. e., suicidal ideation, non-suicidal self-injury, aggressive behavior, and personal safety). The clinician could also ask about a history of the most common psychological patterns, such as sleep difficulties, concentration or memory problems, depression, anxiety, panic, irritability and anger, obsessive thoughts or compulsive behaviors, impulsivity, change in behavior, and interpersonal difficulties. For every psychological symptom endorsed, the clinician should inquire about onset, duration, intensity, frequency, and functional outcomes. The key to exploring the client’s psychological history is to determine whether current symptoms are the primary concern, or secondary to another problem (e. g., attentional difficulties due to trauma history or substance use).

sect2.title: Substance Use History
sect2.para: Given the high prevalence of substance use in the general population (see Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, 2023 ), clinicians should always inquire about substance use regardless of diagnostic hypotheses. Further, many DSM disorders include a substance use rule-out because because the side effects of substances often parallel symptoms of the disorder (e. g., elevated heart rate after stimulant use versus somatic symptoms of anxiety; anhedonia with alcohol and cannabis use versus symptoms of depression; cognitive inefficiency or attentional difficulties associated with cannabis use versus ADHD).

When screening for substance use, the clinician should obtain information about the date of last use, quantity used,frequency frequency and duration of use, route of administration (oral, nasal/snort, smoke, inject, other), and any negative effects resulting from continued use (e. g., withdrawal, tolerance, functional or social problems, etc.). Questions should be sequenced starting with the less stigmatizing legal drugs (caffeine, tobacco, alcohol) followed by questions about illicit drug use and misuse of prescription drugs. Based on the prevalence of substance use in the general population, taking the stance that a client is using or has used a substance may also result in more accurate responses from the client (e. g., “Tell me about your alcohol use” versus “Do you drink?”). If a client denies using a substance, the clinician should inquire about the client’s reasons for non-use. For example, the interviewer could ask, “What made you decide not to drink?” Structuring the interview in this manner reduces stigma and patterns of embarrassment or defensiveness and increases the likelihood that clients will respond openly.

Instead of asking about “illicit” or “street drug” use, the clinician should ask about each substance use category specifically (e. g., opiates, stimulants, etc.). Terminology should also be explained carefully to ensure the client understands the language as intended. For example, when asking about prescription drug use, clients’ knowledge of the term “misuse” may vary based on experience or sociocultural understanding. For screening purposes, the term “misuse” should be defined as taking a prescription medication medication in a way that it needs to be refilled more frequently than ordered, taking medications for purposes other than the way they were prescribed, or taking medications that were not prescribed to the client. Interviewers should also be familiar with commonly used and misused substances. During the evaluation, the interviewer may want to conduct a review of the client’s medical problems and medication list in collaboration with the client, specifically asking about chronic health problems that may result in overuse of medications (e. g., chronic pain) and patterns of use for medications that are commonly misused.

sect2.title: Trauma History
sect2.para: Exposure to a potentially traumatic event (PTE; e. g., witnessing death, serious accident or injury, life-threatening illness, violent encounters) is common, with over 70% of people experiencing one PTE and over 30% experiencing four or more PTEs in their lifetime (Benjet et al., 2016 ). Though most people exposed exposed to a PTE will recover without treatment, approximately 8% go on to develop posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD; Koenen et al., 2017 ). Clients with a trauma history often present with co-occurring physical and mental health disorders (e. g., chronic pain and headaches, cardiovascular disease, metabolic disease, insomnia, anxiety, depression, personality disorders, substance use disorders, and suicidal behaviors).

Despite the high prevalence rate and negative impacts of trauma on well-being, many clients do not report traumatic events or associated symptoms to their providers (~58% seek treatment; Koenen et al., 2017 ). Because clients may not spontaneously provide information about their trauma history, clinicians should inquire directly, even if PTSD is not one of the diagnostic hypotheses hypotheses . If the client endorses a history of exposure to a PTE, the interviewer should follow up with additional questions to differentiate PTSD from other disorders. For example, symptoms of hyperarousal and avoidance also occur with generalized anxiety, depression, and substance use disorders. PTSD can be differentiated from other disorders through the presence of re-experiencing symptoms such as nightmares and flashbacks.

When screening for a history of trauma, it is critically important to exercise clinical sensitivity. Interviewers should avoid the use of potentially triggering explicit terms such as “abuse” and “rape, which may carry different meanings meanings for the client than for the interviewer (e. g., forced sexual intercourse or assault by a stranger versus forced sexual intercourse by any other person). For example, a client may not identify an experience as “rape” but may report having been forced to engage in sexual intercourse. Additionally, sociocultural stereotypes and gender norms may influence how people perceive certain traumatic events (e. g., the belief that rape only happens to women). By approaching the interview with clinical sensitivity, interviewers can create a safe, non-judgmental space for clients to share their experiences.

sect2.title: Safety
sect2.para: Suicide is an urgent and growing public health crisis with lasting effects on individuals, families, and communities. Mental health professionals have an ethical obligation and responsibility to protect clients from imminent danger to themselves and others (Simone & Fulero, 2005 ). When conducting a diagnostic interview, regardless of the specific referral question or diagnostic considerations considerations , it is incumbent on the clinician to assess for safety, including questions about suicidal thoughts, non-suicidal self-injury, thoughts of harming others, and personal safety. Specific to protecting others, clinicians have a “duty to warn” (Tarasoff I; responsibility to warn potential victims if clients present a serious threat of harm) and a “duty to protect” (Tarasoff II; reasonable steps must be taken to protect potential victims from harm, even if confidentiality is violated). Mental health professionals are responsible for understanding the legal mandates in the jurisdiction where they practice.

During a diagnostic interview, the clinician should always assess for safety concerns. This can be done by asking direct questions and utilizing evidence-based screening tools (e. g., Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale; Posner et al., 2011 ). During the interview, one strategy is to ask direct and open-ended questions questions about the client’s current state of mind, including thoughts of suicidal ideation, self-harm, harm to others, and personal safety (e. g., “Have you had thoughts about harming yourself or others,” “Do any of your physical, cognitive, or emotional symptoms ever create situations that are dangerous for you or threatening to others,” “Do you feel safe in your home or other environments?”). In addition to direct questioning, observing non-verbal cues such as body language, facial expressions, and tone of voice can also provide valuable insights. Evaluating the client’s support system, access to weapons or harmful substances, and recent life stressors can help gauge their level of risk.

If the client reports safety concerns, it may be necessary to pause or deviate from the initially planned interview and shift focus to a crisis assessment and management. To understand the severity of the safety concern, it is important to evaluate the immediacy and intensity of the expressed thoughts or behaviors, considering factors such as frequency, duration, and level of distress experienced. Additionally, the clinician must inquire about the client’s level of intent, whether they have conceived conceived of or made any plans, and whether they can carry out any harmful actions. Assessing for protective factors, such as supportive relationships, coping skills, and reasons for living, can provide valuable insights into the client’s resilience and potential for safety. It’s essential to consider the context of the individual’s life circumstances, including recent stressors or traumatic events, which may exacerbate their safety concerns. Finally, when assessing safety, it is crucial to establish rapport and trust to encourage honesty and disclosure while being prepared to intervene or refer for immediate help if necessary.

sect1.sect2:
Delusions and Hallucinations
It is good clinical interviewing practice to ask all clients about current and past episodes of psychosis. Psychosis involves disruptions in both the content and process of thought, leading to impairments in a person’s ability to manage the demands of daily life. Delusions are strongly held, false beliefs that are maintained by the client despite evidence to the contrary. Common delusions include themes themes of persecution (e. g., feeling as though they are being harassed, watched, followed, conspired against, etc.), grandiosity (e. g., feeling as though they are more important than others; having special powers), and somatic (e. g., a person of male sex believing they are pregnant; missing or extra body parts). Hallucinations are sensory perceptions of things that are not there. Though hallucinations can occur in any sensory process, auditory hallucinations are the most common common for people with psychiatric concerns and typically align with the content of delusions (when present). For example, a client with persecutory delusions may hear voices expressing derogatory statements toward them. When a client endorses auditory hallucinations, the clinician must inquire about the presence of command hallucinations, which are voices that instruct a person to do something. Because they are less likely to occur independently, clients presenting with visual, smell, taste, or tactile hallucinations may be experiencing the sensation secondary to another problem (e. g., traumatic brain injury, substance intoxication, medical concerns, sleep deprivation, dehydration, etc.; Green, 2002 ).3.3Table 3.3 people people

Other Psychological History Sample Questions
Area of inquiry
Sample interview questions
Other psychological history
• Have you ever been told by a physical or mental health provider that you have a mental health problem or brain injury? (if yes, inquire about details)
• If yes, have your mental health symptoms been stable (stable w/ treatment or meds; stable w/out treatment or meds; unstable)
General substance use history
• What substances do you use (caffeine, tobacco, alcohol, cannabis, sedative/hypnotics, hallucinogens, inhalants, opioids, stimulants, other)?
• If not currently using, what is the reason for non-use?
•(if multiple substances are used) what is your current drug or substance of choice?
• Have you used any substances in the last 48 hours? If yes, what?
Specific substance use questions (should be asked for each substance the client endorses)
• Tell me about your use of (substance x)—Route of administration, age at first use, last time used, typical consumption in one episode of use, situations when you use, negative consequences of use, and treatment attempts
• Have there been periods of time since you started using (substance x) that you did not use? Longest period of abstinence?
• What happens physically or emotionally when you stop using (substance x)? (for example, body aches, headaches, nausea, irritability, depression, anxiety).
• Are you currently experiencing withdrawal symptoms, such as tremors, excessive sweating, rapid heart rate, anxiety, vomiting, seizures, etc.?
• Do you find yourself using more (substance x) to get the same effect?
• Inquire about overdose history: Have you ever lost consciousness or needed medical intervention after using (substance x)? How recent was your last overdose?
Alcohol use
• How many drinks to you have on an average drinking day (note: Be sure to clarify the size and strength of a typical drink for the client. For example, a 12-ounce beer will have a different effect than a shot of vodka.)
• Binge drinking: In the last 30 days, how often have you had: (for females) four or more drinks on one occasion, (for males) five or more drinks on one occasion?
Prescription drug misuse
• Do you ever need to take more medication than prescribed to get the intended effects?
• Have you ever taken medication that was prescribed for someone else?
Trauma history
• Have you ever been beaten, slapped, shoved, kicked, or punched?
• Have you had sexual activity when you didn’t want to, because someone forced you, or you didn’t think you could refuse?
• Have you experienced a disaster, accident, or serious injury?
• Did any of these things happen to someone you are close to, or did you witness any of these things happening to someone else?
• When did each event occur (e. g., how old were you)?
Trauma history: Symptom screen
• How do you typically react when reminded of past traumatic experiences?
• Have you noticed any changes in your mood or feelings, or had nightmares or flashbacks since experiencing the event(s)?
• Are there any specific triggers that tend to bring back memories or feelings related to the event(s)?
• Do you find yourself avoiding situations, places, or people that remind you of the traumatic event(s)? Have you tried hard not to think about the event(s)?
• Do you often feel on edge, easily startled, or have difficulty sleeping?
Safety
• Harm to self: Have you had thoughts of hurting yourself or that you would be better off dead? If yes, are you having those thoughts today? Have you ever acted on these feelings to hurt yourself?
• Harm to others: Have you had thoughts of harming others? If yes, are you having these thoughts today? Have you ever acted on these feelings to harm others?
• Personal safety: Do you feel safe at home? Do any of your current relationships pose a threat to your safety? If yes, has this person threatened or used a weapon against you or your children? If yes, do you think this person might try to kill you?
• General safety: Do any other current situations in your life pose a threat to your safety?
• Do any of your physical, cognitive, or emotional symptoms ever create situations that are dangerous for you or threatening to others?
Delusions
• Persecution: Do you ever feel like other people are out to harm you or that you are being harassed, watched, followed, or conspired against?
• Grandiosity: Do you ever feel that you are especially important in some way that others may not understand or as though you have some special power or ability that other people do not have?
• Somatic: Do you ever feel that something is happening to your body that other people, including your medical providers, cannot explain?
Hallucinations
• Have you had any strange or unusual experiences that you can’t explain?
• Do you ever hear things that other people say they do not hear, such as noises or the voices of other people whispering or talking?
• Do you ever have visions or see things that other people say they cannot see? Do you ever see or hear things that you know are not real, such as people, animals, bugs, etc.? Are the things you see static (not moving) or interactive and moving around in your environment?
• Tell me about your emotional state, such as feeling of depression, anxiety, or fear, when you most often have these experiences
